titleStmt.title: Burlesque upon Magistracy; or, Punch out of Humour

notesStmt.note: A thief disguises himself as a magistrate

Burlesque upon Magistracy; or, Punch out of Humour is a play printed in London and in Dublin in 1736. The title page indicates that the show can be seen at the “Roiting House" of a certain Don Parabocka, but that its script is printed because it is entirely new and an "intelligent interpreter" has not yet been found.

normalization.p: The semi-diplomatic norms applied are intended to guide and facilitate the reading of the original texts. The transcriptions therefore include spelling and grammatical corrections according to current standards.
The author's orthographic and grammatical corrections have been integrated into the text without being marked. Cuts for performance purposes have not been adopted in the transcription.
Syntax has been modernised where it is naturally incorrect or has become incomprehensible today. Additions are limited and indicated by square brackets.
The copyist's obvious errors (scene numbers, character attributions, etc.) have been corrected. The list of characters could also be corrected.

punctuation.p: Punctuation has been corrected according to modern rules.

projectDesc.p: Text collected during the PuppetPlays project funded by European Union (Grant Agreement 835193) under Horizon 2020. The PuppetPlays project aims to re-evaluate the contribution of the puppets repertoire to the construction of European cultural identity. Its main goals is to collect a corpus of representative plays from Western Europe (Germany, Austria, Belgium, Spain, France, Great Britain, Italy, Netherlands, Portugal, Switzerland) between the 17th and the 21th century. It also tries to identify the characteristics of puppet dramaturgy and their variations depending on eras, cultural spheres, producing conditions, and the aimed public.
This edition is the result of university research work, reviewed by the principal investigator.

castItem.role: And other Attendants, as at a Sessions

div.head: This is to give notice to all Gentlemen, Ladies and others, etc
div.stage: The first figure we present you is Punch, who seems to be in a great fury at some insult he heard had been offered to his sister, Mopsa.

lg.l: By all the Gods, I’ll fret my guts,
To fiddle strings – I’ve learnt my struts –
My honour cannot bear such usage,
Since Father now is on a new stage;
Now sage Gormoncho rules the city,
Now sister Mopsa’s grown so pretty;
I’ll teach those riotous defamers,
Of what respect we now are claimers;
I’ll vengence have, confound me, will I,
Must Punch be thought for ever silly?

div.stage: Gentlemen and Ladies pray take notice, the next figure we present you is the beautiful Mopsa, encouraging her brother Punch to hasten his revenge.

lg.l: Dear Brother, by your ties of duty,
Redress the wrong that’s done my beauty;
Was ever tender maid so hurted,
By one whom I so often have courted?
Whom I – (but may my curses catch him)
Oh, haste, dear Fatty, to dispatch him –
My injuries I’ve often repeated,
Wants still your courage to be whetted?
Mopsa, I own I’m flow of thinking,
Oft’ are my senses fog’d by drinking;
Nor is my courage of the quickest,
Unless a tender point thou prickest.
But now, as you were just appearing,
I have been swaggering, storming, swearing;
No boyling water is more frothy,
No Captain Bluff was half so wrothy;
When quick – strange chilliness of blood!
Confounded at your sight I stood ---
I shook more fast than leaf of aspin,
My throat I thought Alanio grasping;
No culverin discharged was quieter,
I fancy ev’ry bush a rioter ---
My fears are now again defeated,
Repeat your wrongs, to keep me heated.
No – dastardly misshapen Elfe,
I’ll execute my rage myself –
To old Gormoncho I’ll complain,
Papa don’t bear the rod in vain;
I know he hates Alanio’s kindred,
To all his Friends has malice inbred;
Will punish for his filthy song,
No matter whether right or wrong.
But see – he makes his publick entry –
What crowds of corporation gentry!
See how he struts it in regalia –
So oft’ I’ve seen of Ham Westfalia;
Fat slices graced with leaves of laurel,
Or ill-sav’d God in clean hoop’d Barrel –
But what care I, how much uncomely,
He looks – so I my Vengeance come by –

div.stage: The next figure we present you is the sage Gormoncho, with a white wand in his hand, Not unlike a mayor’s rod, he should have made His appearance in the regalia that his daughter Mopsa fancies him drest in, but as we were coming to this town, a vagabond fellow, who had once been Sub-Sheriff of the county G ---, and was obliged to fly for malpractices, met us on the road, and robbed us of them all.

lg.l: Call in Wyario – fix my cushion,
See that no bold insulters rush on –
In silence let the mob adore us,
Let all complainants come before us –
But first Wyario, read the indictment,
For our regalia that by slight went --
For tho delinquent’s non inventus,
To find the bill that shan’t prevent us;
I can the vagrant paint minutely;
His birth and life know most acutely –
And, tho’s our daughter has a grievance,
That wants (she says) our quick relievance;
Yet since that’s but a private evil,
To hear a public wrong’s more civil.

div.stage: Here Wyario reads a long accusation against persons unknown, for robbing the Show-Man of his regalia, as also a proclamation with reward to anyone that shall discover the thief, and then concludes as you shall hear.

lg.l: Oyes – It is his worship’s pleasure,
All people hear his tale at leisure.
Good burghers, councilmen and commons,
Know you, for what I sent my summons;
I sent – because in public meeting,
To tell such vilanies is fitting;
That so by many one’s assistance,
We’ll nab the rogue tho’ now at distance –
This wretch (tho’ once I thought him honest
Often if men our notion’s wrongest)
From poor but virtuous folk took birth,
Far westward on our Irish earth.
His parents held a decent dwelling,
Fit for their calling, good ale selling,
This I know well for to this minute,
They still live there, and draw ale in it –
Their son (our royal robes purloiner,
Don’t think I’m of a fiction coiner)
With Sub-Attorney served as [ap]prentice,
From thence to act as Sheriff sent is;
The county’s money (strong temptation,
For such a reptile education)
Is wisely to his trust committed,
And he as well the county fitted;
He humbly owns himself their debtor
Will reimburse, when times are better;
But for the present begs excuse,
He’ll put your money out to use –
This forced the wretch to skulk among us,
Waiting for power and time to wrong us –
His make is of the lower stature,
Tho’ vile his heart, has smiling feature;
And when in private has undone you,
Is most in public fawning on you;
His paunch rotu[nd] and somewhat gross is,
Near my own size he pretty close is;
By this d[e]scription you may guess him,
Dear friends be zealous, to suppress him,
Now Mopsa, child, declare, why grieve you,
Your father’s power shall soon relieve you.
Good Sir, were not that Punch a coward,
More base than is your serjeant H-;
Your Worship need not now be vext,
Nor my young heart so long perplex –
But since he’s frighted – this my Case is –
And sure you’ll think it worth redress is –
One night (your Worship then was farming)
As in my bed I just was warming;
I heard (don’t bid me sp[ea]ke it plainly)
I heard Alanio sing obscenely;
His song I can’t repeat so naught it,
His voice it was or so I thought it –
And sure to know that voice was easy,
That voice had once sole power to please me;
Surprized at such an odd proceeding,
I rose to check his want of breeding;
Perhaps abused him in my passion,
For full my heart was of vexation;
To hear him such affronts negotiate,
With Porabock that vile associate;
The whole abuse I don’t remember,
I know he wished me some good member
(So chast[e] my mind it did not strike it)
For Sir indeed, I do not like it,
He comes – Oh punish such offenses,
His very sight distracts my senses –

div.stage: The figure we present you is Alanio, who comes attented with two constables to arrest Gormoncho, who tho’ arrived to, and concealed under the magistracy, is at last dicovered to be the very rogue that stole the regalia. But before Alanio has time to sp[ea]ke, Gormoncho bawls out.

lg.l: Sergeants, my friends, secure that vil[l]ain,
Here you Wyario, bring the bill in;
That slave shall feel my utmost fury –
(Since brother burghers are his jury) (Aside)
Deluded people read this warrant, (Your ruler proves a knave most arrant)
From western justices directed –
His full blown crimes are now detected –
This is the very rogue you fought for,
Such a vile wretch who can say ought for
Your Pris[o]ner, quickly, sergeants, haul away,
Strip him, and send him back to G -
A Moral in our little Shew is
Nor it’s design so hard to know is.
